common.discarded_message: This frame has been discarded from analysis.
common.processing_video: Processing video sequences using a Recurrent Neural Network (RNN)

about.title: Project Information
about.name: Pablo Argallero Fernández
about.p1_start: This research initiative represents the academic evolution of the
about.p1_end: shifting focus from pure detection accuracy to interpretability and transparency in AI systems. The primary objective is to contribute to the scientific community by producing a detailed paper on Explainable AI (XAI) applied to forensic video analysis.
about.p2: Building upon the original hybrid CNN-RNN architecture, I implemented advanced interpretability mechanisms to visualize the model’s decision-making process:
about.li1: Integrated to generate visual explanations, highlighting regions that triggered classification.
about.li2: Novel visualization to track pixel-level anomalies across temporal sequences.
about.li3: Intuitive presentation of complex visual metrics to bridge the gap between inference and understanding.
about.p3: This work not only refines the technical prowess of the detection engine but also addresses ethical AI concerns by providing verifiable proofs for every classification.
about.collab: In collaboration with the University of Oviedo and professor Cristian González García.

body.upload_desc: To ensure server security, video uploading is restricted. If you don't have a password, you can use the Demo mode or contact me to request access.
body.processing_desc: This may take a few minutes
body.intro_p1: The increasing use of artificial intelligence has enabled identity impersonation through DeepFakes, synthetic content generated by AI algorithms that combine and overlay existing images and videos to create a new one.
body.intro_p2: The realism achieved using current DeepFake algorithms poses a risk to society. From 'fake news' to identity theft, AI-generated content makes it increasingly difficult to distinguish real from fake.
body.intro_p3: This DeepFake detection tool aims to help identify synthetic material through predictive model analysis.

cnn.processed_tooltip: Frame used for prediction after rotation and crop.
cnn.heatmap_tooltip: Temporal changes compared to previous frame.
cnn.gradcam_tooltip: AI attention regions for the prediction.
cnn.heatmap_error_0: Heatmap can not be computed for first frame of the video

cnn.title: CNN Analysis Tutorial
cnn.step1_content: This dashboard allows you to analyze a video frame by frame. It's composed of three main sections: statistics, visualization, and temporal analysis.
cnn.step2_content: Here you can see global statistics. The Pie Chart helps you visualize how many frames are categorized as 'Fake' based on the Decision Threshold. You can adjust this threshold to set your own 'baremo' (baseline) for detection.
cnn.step3_content: You have two ways to investigate: the 'Video' tab for a rough analysis (a groso modo) to quickly locate suspicious segments, and the 'Images' tab for deep forensic analysis.
cnn.step4_content: In 'Images' mode, we show: Processed (AI input), Heatmaps (motion/changes), and Grad-CAM (where the AI is looking). You can click any image to expand it for a closer look.
cnn.step5_content: This chart shows the evolution of fake probability throughout the video. Use it to identify specific spikes in the analysis.

rnn.title: RNN Analysis Tutorial
rnn.step1_content: This dashboard analyzes patterns across sequences of frames using a Recurrent Neural Network.
rnn.step2_content: These metrics represent the results across sequence blocks. The Pie Chart shows the overall distribution between Real and Deepfake based on your threshold.
rnn.step3_content: The video player shows the specific sequence being analyzed, allowing you to correlate visual patterns with the model's predictions.
rnn.step4_content: This chart analyzes trends in 20-frame blocks, showing how the prediction evolves over the duration of the video.
